author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in June
description: Our picks for June, including ‘Queer Eye,’ ‘Da 5 Bloods,’ ‘Scarface’ and ‘LOL: Last One Laughing Australia’
content: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Rick Rojas
title: Amid Riots and a Pandemic, Church Attendance Resumes in ‘a Very Broken World’
description: In communities across the country, congregations that had sequestered for months to avoid the coronavirus ventured forth at a social distance in search of comfort.
content: SACRAMENTO — With their most vulnerable members at home, their community in the streets, and their nation wracked by a pandemic, riots and political polarization, Pastor Samuel Rodriguez’s congregation went to church here on Sunday, at times violating state health rules in the interest of unity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: June 1, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 1, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 1, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Zombi Child’ and ‘Inside Man’
description: Bertrand Bonello’s recent film makes its streaming debut on the Criterion Channel. And the heist movie starring Denzel Washington and Jodie Foster arrives on Netflix.
content: ZOMBI CHILD (2019) Stream on the Criterion Channel. To seal her membership in an exclusive clique at the prestigious French boarding school she attends, Mélissa (Wislanda Louimat) is forced to share “something personal” with her new friends. The secret she reveals, which is foreshadowed by the film’s opening scenes set in Haiti in 1962, is not a typical teenage confession. She reveals that the aunt she lives with is a Haitian Voodoo priestess whose father was brought back from the dead as a zombie and enslaved. One of the girls in attendance, Fanny (Louise Labèque), is intrigued by the revelation. She hopes that Mélissa’s living relative will help her address an erotic obsession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Fires Near White House During Protests in Washington
description: Fires burned in the streets just before a citywide curfew went into effect. Police officers fired tear gas to dissuade protesters. And smoke was seen rising near the Washington Monument.
content: Fires burned in the streets just before a citywide curfew went into effect. Police officers fired tear gas to dissuade protesters. And smoke was seen rising near the Washington Monument.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Bennet
title: When the Protesters Carried Guns
description: What if the protesters in Minneapolis had adopted the tactics of the anti-lockdown agitators?
content: This article is part of the Opinion Today free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Carlsen and Ken Belson
title: For Sidelined N.F.L. Brothers, Training Is a Snap
description: Reid and Blake Ferguson are long snappers, housemates and training partners during an off-season that, so far, has no end date.
content: When the coronavirus pandemic forced the N.F.L. to shutter its training facilities in March and ban all travel, thousands of players had to hunker down at home like the rest of us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By K.K. Rebecca Lai
title: Chants, Clashes and Hundreds of Arrests: What Happened at the Protests in New York City
description: Thousands of people gathered across the city over the weekend at protests prompted by the death of George Floyd, who died last week after a police officer in Minneapolis knelt on his neck for nearly nine minutes.
content: Thousands of people gathered across the city over the weekend at protests prompted by the death of George Floyd, who died last week after a police officer in Minneapolis knelt on his neck for nearly nine minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Engel Bromwich
title: How a Minnesota Bail Fund Raised $20 Million
description: After the killing of George Floyd, a small Minneapolis fund that is paying bail for protesters saw a huge influx of donations.
content: A small Minneapolis bail fund has received millions of dollars in funding from people after the killing of George Floyd, a black man who died on Memorial Day after a white police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexa Weibel
title: Ferran Adrià’s Potato Chip Omelet Delights Beyond Expectation
description: Created as a family meal dish for the El Bulli staff a decade ago, this three-ingredient dish utilizes pantry staples.
content: Even if you haven’t worked in a restaurant, the concept of family meal may be familiar: It’s the act of cobbling together a meal that salvages or repurposes ingredients to resourcefully feed a restaurant’s staff before service, and, ideally, to connect them at the table. The frugality of this kind of meal can be thrilling — it’s a marriage of hospitality and practicality — and it exemplifies how many Americans are preparing food right now, as many home cooks have leaned into making focaccia, growing victory gardens and stretching staple ingredients.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Five Artists for This Moment
description: These esteemed black American creators make work that responds to violence against the black body.
content: Yet another instance of searing racial injustice in this country, the death of George Floyd has galvanized people far and wide to demand change. Their efforts are a reminder that protest and consciousness-raising come in many forms. Sometimes, it is aesthetic in nature: “The power of the art of public engagement is in how, after news cycles and public outrage have moved on, it makes us see the things we don’t want to,” T’s writer at large Megan O’Grady writes in her 2018 piece on the performance artist Pope.L, best known for his physically punishing crawls through city streets. He, along with Nick Cave, Carrie Mae Weems, Arthur Jafa and the fashion designer Kerby Jean-Raymond, is among the contemporary artists who make work that addresses violence against the black body, presenting their audiences with reflections and refractions of our shared past and present. Here are profiles of each one of them, along with pictures of their powerful work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Moss
title: George Floyd’s Final Words, Written in the Sky
description: On Saturday, the artist Jammie Holmes staged his own kind of protest in five cities across the country.
content: Just after 12:30 p.m. on Saturday, as cooped-up New Yorkers spilled onto the Battery Park City esplanade — most in groups of two or three, each stationed a safe distance apart — a small plane glided past the Statue of Liberty and into view over the Hudson River. A banner swelled behind it, which read, “They’re Going to Kill Me.” These were among the last words of George Floyd, a black man who was killed while in the custody of the Minneapolis Police Department on May 25, and whose death has spurred demonstrations all over the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Joel Revzen, Conductor and Music Festival Leader, Dies at 74
description: Mr. Revzen, who had the coronavirus, held posts with regional companies and was on the staff of the Metropolitan Opera.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: Mass Extinctions Are Accelerating, Scientists Report
description: Five hundred species are likely to become extinct over the next two decades, according to a new study.
content: We are in the midst of a mass extinction, many scientists have warned — this one driven not by a catastrophic natural event, but by humans. The unnatural loss of biodiversity is accelerating, and if it continues, the planet will lose vast ecosystems and the necessities they provide, including fresh water, pollination, and pest and disease control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Wallace Stegner and the Conflicted Soul of the West
description: In his first installment of a new series on overlooked or under-read American writers, A.O. Scott, a critic at large for The New York Times, considers Wallace Stegner, the Western novelist who captured, and criticized, his region’s individualistic spirit.
content: I FOUND MY WAY to Wallace Stegner by accident. Really through three identical accidents, lightning strikes that I’m only now beginning to suspect were signs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Fall Is Now Jam-Packed for Book Publishers. That Could Be a Problem.
description: Books scheduled for release this spring and summer are now on track for fall, when authors will be fighting for attention in the midst of a presidential election and an ongoing crisis.
content: In March, when parts of the United States began shutting down because of the coronavirus, the best-selling children’s book author Jeff Kinney faced a dilemma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Cook for Comfort
description: It can be hard to cook in times like these, but do it all the same.
content: Good morning. It was a weekend of unrest and fury, and the rest of the news is terrible, too. You may begin this week exhausted, anxious, worried about the future, your health, your place in the world. It can be hard to seek pleasure when that’s the case. It can be hard to cook.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Protests in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
description: New York City descended into chaos for a fourth night  after largely peaceful demonstrations over the death of George Floyd.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Video Appears to Show a Tanker Truck Driving Into Minneapolis Protesters
description: The truck can be seen speeding toward protesters on a highway as demonstrations continued in Minneapolis for the sixth straight night.
content: The truck can be seen speeding toward protesters on a highway as demonstrations continued in Minneapolis for the sixth straight night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: How Zane Lowe Became Pop’s Unofficial Therapist
description: The D.J.’s interviews on Apple’s Beats 1 have gone from promotional stops to opportunities for deep thoughts, anchored by an impulse to share his own story.
content: Justin Bieber cried. Hayley Williams too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louise Palmberg
title: Finding Euphoria in Bangkok’s Food Scene
description: In search of creative inspiration, a New York-based photographer spent two weeks documenting Bangkok’s fresh markets and street vendors.
content: With travel restrictions in place worldwide, we’ve launched a new series, The World Through a Lens, in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Louise Palmberg shares a collection of photographs from the markets and food stands in Bangkok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix, Amazon and More in June
description: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are our picks for June.
content: For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carrie Mae Weems
title: Carrie Mae Weems: A Crack in the Cultural Armor
description: The artist recounts the genesis of her photo series on the sets and spaces where African Americans changed network television.
content: This photo essay is part of The Big Ideas, a special section of The Times’s philosophy series, The Stone, in which more than a dozen artists, writers and thinkers answer the question, “Why does art matter?” The entire series can be found here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Protest Scenes Across California
description: Demonstrations in many California cities have taken place to protest the death of George Floyd while he was in police custody in Minneapolis.
content: Demonstrations in many California cities have taken place to protest the death of George Floyd while he was in police custody in Minneapolis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wippman and Glenn Altschuler
title: How Colleges Can Keep the Coronavirus Off Campus
description: Schools must build cultures of physical distancing to protect campuses.
content: Colleges and universities like ours are hoping to reopen campuses and resume in-person instruction in the fall, but they face significant physical and logistical obstacles in protecting their students. Residential colleges are sometimes described as “landlocked cruise ships,” because students live, eat, study and socialize together, often in close quarters. Under ordinary circumstances, that is a good thing. But such tightly knit campus communities are tailor-made for spreading an easily transmissible illness like the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Oat Milk Powers This Ice Cream
description: A new offering from Planet Oat Frozen Desserts is silky smooth and comes in six flavors.
content: Planet Oat Frozen Desserts has introduced nondairy frozen desserts in six flavors: vanilla, chocolate, cookies and crème, coffee fudge swirl, chocolate peanut butter swirl and blueberry oat crumble. The collection of six is notable for its smooth texture; they behave like ice cream. Aside from the rather sweet blandness of the vanilla, the others are very appealing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Economy Faces Long-Term Recovery, C.B.O. Says: Live Updates
description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: The Congressional Budget Office projected on Monday that the coronavirus pandemic could cost the United States economy $16 trillion over the next 10 years. When adjusting for inflation, the pandemic is projected to cause a $7.9 trillion, or 3 percent, loss in “real” G.D.P. through 2030.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman and Elizabeth Paton
title: The Virgil Abloh Backlash
description: The Off-White and Louis Vuitton designer has become a target of social media anger and frustration because of statements about the protests.
content: In 2018, when Louis Vuitton named Virgil Abloh as its men’s wear artistic director, it made Mr. Abloh, the founder of Off-White, a Nike collaborator and the former creative director for Kanye West, one of the first black designers at the top of a French heritage house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gonzalez
title: New York’s Days of Protest: What It Looked Like From the Streets
description: These are our most striking photos from five days of protest where crowds of demonstrators stopped traffic and clashed with police.
content: After weeks of being cooped up to stay alive, thousands of New Yorkers have taken to the city’s streets to protest a death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rubenstein
title: The G.O.P. Tosses Steve King Overboard
description: The Iowa congressman is too much, even for the party of Donald Trump. He still might win.
content: Steve King, the suicidally outspoken Republican representing Iowa’s Fourth Congressional District, is facing the first serious primary challenge of his 17-year congressional career. He has little to show for his time in Congress. He has been stripped of his committee assignments, he’s out of campaign cash and has few friends in Congress. The state and national party have all but abandoned him.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Economy Faces Long-Term Recovery, C.B.O. Says: Live Updates
description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: The Congressional Budget Office projected on Monday that the coronavirus pandemic could cost the United States economy $16 trillion over the next 10 years. When adjusting for inflation, the pandemic is projected to cause a $7.9 trillion, or 3 percent, loss in “real” G.D.P. through 2030.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gonzalez
title: New York’s Days of Protest: What It Looked Like From the Streets
description: These are our most striking photos from five days of protest where crowds of demonstrators stopped traffic and clashed with police.
content: After weeks of being cooped up to stay alive, thousands of New Yorkers have taken to the city’s streets to protest a death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Abused Woman Who Killed Husband Is Granted the Family’s U.K. Estate
description: Sally Challen’s landmark case has put a spotlight on the fight against domestic abuse in Britain.
content: A British woman who was convicted of killing her husband after decades of emotional abuse is entitled to the family’s estate, a judge has ruled — the latest development in a case that has gripped Britain for years and exposed the challenges of confronting domestic abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: U.S. and Chinese Scientists Trace Evolution of Coronaviruses in Bats
description: Researchers whose canceled U.S. grant caused an outcry from other scientists urge preventive monitoring of viruses in southwestern China.
content: An international team of scientists, including a prominent researcher at the Wuhan Institute of Virology, has analyzed all known coronaviruses in Chinese bats and used genetic analysis to trace the likely origin of the novel coronavirus to horseshoe bats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: China Offers Measured Response to Trump’s Move on Hong Kong
description: A foreign ministry spokesman stayed close to the Communist Party’s official position on Hong Kong, suggesting that Beijing was waiting to see the specifics of the U.S. plan.
content: After staying quiet for days following President Trump’s move to curtail relations with Hong Kong, Beijing weighed in on Monday with a relatively measured response, suggesting that it might be waiting for details about Washington’s plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A Filmmaker Put Away for Tax Fraud Takes Us Inside a British Prison
description: In “A Bit of a Stretch,” Chris Atkins writes about the nine months he spent at Wandsworth, one of the largest, oldest and unruliest prisons in Britain.
content: There’s lockdown, and then there’s lockdown. Chris Atkins, a successful English filmmaker, got involved in a tax-dodging scheme to finance a documentary. He was sentenced to five years in prison, and was sent to Wandsworth — one of the largest, oldest and unruliest prisons in Britain. If he stood on the dismal toilet in his cell, he could sometimes see the London skyline.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Our Nation Is Falling Apart’
description: A reader cites the many miseries facing the U.S. and laments the president’s “utter failure to provide the requisite leadership.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: U.S. Ruling Could Mean a Flood of New Claims Against Volkswagen
description: Judges on Monday cleared the way for counties to pursue the automaker, which has already paid more than $20 billion in federal penalties for cheating on pollution tests, under local laws.
content: Volkswagen, the German automaker that admitted to a decade-long scheme to cheat on diesel emissions tests in the United States and elsewhere, could face a “staggering” volume of claims from local governments after a federal appeals court ruled on Monday that counties in Florida and in Utah could impose local pollution laws on the manufacturer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Trump and Putin Discuss Russia’s Attendance at G7, but Allies Are Wary
description: The British and Canadian governments oppose admitting Russia into the bloc, as President Trump continues a renewed courtship of Russia’s leader.
content: President Trump and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke by telephone on Monday, two days after Mr. Trump said he would invite Mr. Putin to attend a Group of 7 summit in the United States in September, the latest instance of a renewed round of personal diplomacy between the two leaders this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Williams Walsh and Matt Phillips
title: Poor Countries Face a Debt Crisis ‘Unlike Anything We Have Seen’
description: Dozens of countries that borrowed from private investors have debt payments coming due as their economies have crashed because of the coronavirus.
content: From Angola to Jamaica to Ecuador to Zambia, the world’s poor countries have had their finances shredded by the global pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Protests Spur Surge in Donations, Giving ActBlue Its Biggest Day of the Year
description: With money flowing to candidates, bail funds and charities, the Democrats’ online donor platform processed over $60 million between Friday and Monday, a sign of strength for the party.
content: The mass protests that have swept the nation in recent days to express outrage at the death of George Floyd have been paired with a flood of financial donations, as hundreds of thousands of Americans have opened their wallets to give to charitable groups, community bail funds and Democratic candidates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Trump and Putin Discuss Russia’s Attendance at G7, but Allies Are Wary
description: The British and Canadian governments oppose admitting Russia into the bloc, as President Trump continues a renewed courtship of Russia’s leader.
content: President Trump and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke by telephone on Monday, two days after Mr. Trump said he would invite Mr. Putin to attend a Group of 7 summit in the United States in September, the latest instance of a renewed round of personal diplomacy between the two leaders this year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Filmmaker Put Away for Tax Fraud Takes Us Inside a British Prison

He was sentenced to five years in prison, and was sent to Wandsworth — one of the largest, oldest and unruliest prisons in Britain. If he stood on the dismal toilet in his cell, he could sometimes see the London skyline.
source.name: The New York Times

content: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and Chinese Scientists Trace Evolution of Coronaviruses in Bats

title: Abused Woman Who Killed Husband Is Granted the Family’s U.K. Estate
description: Sally Challen’s landmark case has put a spotlight on the fight against domestic abuse in Britain.
content: A British woman who was convicted of killing her husband after decades of emotional abuse is entitled to the family’s estate, a judge has ruled — the latest development in a case that has gripped Britain for years and exposed the challenges of confronting domestic abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: China Offers Measured Response to Trump’s Move on Hong Kong
description: A foreign ministry spokesman stayed close to the Communist Party’s official position on Hong Kong, suggesting that Beijing was waiting to see the specifics of the U.S. plan.
content: After staying quiet for days following President Trump’s move to curtail relations with Hong Kong, Beijing weighed in on Monday with a relatively measured response, suggesting that it might be waiting for details about Washington’s plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: New Regulator Warns Health Measures, Like Masks, May Hurt Banks
description: Brian P. Brooks, the acting head of the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, warned state and local leaders that requiring face masks could help bank robbers.
content: The new head of a powerful banking regulator is not letting his first full week on the job pass quietly, warning that measures meant to contain the spread of the coronavirus — including mandates for the use of masks in public — could endanger the financial system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: How You Should Read Coronavirus Studies, or Any Science Paper
description: Published scientific research, like any piece of writing, is a peculiar literary genre.
content: A lot of people are reading scientific papers for the first time these days, hoping to make sense of the coronavirus pandemic. If you’re one of them, be advised the scientific paper is a peculiar literary genre that can take some getting used to. And also bear in mind that these are not typical times for scientific publishing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Williams Walsh and Matt Phillips
title: Poor Countries Face a Debt Crisis ‘Unlike Anything We Have Seen’
description: Dozens of countries that borrowed from private investors have debt payments coming due as their economies have crashed because of the coronavirus.
content: From Angola to Jamaica to Ecuador to Zambia, the world’s poor countries have had their finances shredded by the global pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery
title: Retailers, Battered by Pandemic, Now Confront Protests
description: Even as major chains boarded up stores and halted operations, they largely sought to convey empathy for demonstrators and did not condemn the damage to their businesses.
content: People smashed the front doors of a Walmart in Peoria, Ill. They ransacked an Apple store in Philadelphia and broke the windows at Nordstrom’s flagship in Seattle, its hometown, while throwing merchandise into the crowds outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins, Derek M. Norman and Nate Schweber
title: Shattered Glass in SoHo as Looters Ransack Lower Manhattan
description: As the protesters moved north, fringe groups hung back, setting fires, breaking windows and grabbing goods from a string of luxury boutiques.
content: All Sunday night, the scene repeated itself as protesters moved through Lower Manhattan. After the main marchers would advance, fringe groups would hang back, and then the shattering glass would begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: Misinformation About George Floyd Protests Surges on Social Media
description: In the universe of false online information, Mr. Floyd remains alive and George Soros is to blame for the protests.
content: On Twitter and Facebook, hundreds of posts are circulating saying that George Floyd is not actually dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Medical Workers Should Use Respirator Masks, Not Surgical Masks
description: The surgical masks used in risky settings like hospitals offer much less protection against the coronavirus, an analysis found.
content: A new analysis of 172 studies, funded by the World Health Organization, confirms what scientists have said for months: N95 and other respirator masks are far superior to surgical or cloth masks in protecting essential medical workers against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley
title: Black Workers, Already Lagging, Face Big Economic Risks
description: Black employment rates are plummeting, and the evolving wealth and income hit could fall on the shoulders of those ill-equipped to bear it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: After 6 Months, Important Mysteries About Coronavirus Endure
description: Times journalists summarize some of the most critical things that scientists and public health officials have yet to understand.
content: In the time since the world’s scientists and public health officials first became widely aware of the new coronavirus in January, they’ve had six months to learn about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: U.S. Protests, Coronavirus, SpaceX: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $800,000 Homes in California
description: A Craftsman bungalow in Santa Monica, a renovated Edwardian house in Oakland and a Tudor Revival cottage in Napa.
content: This home, in the Ocean Park neighborhood of Santa Monica, ispart of the Third Street Historic District. A Craftsman bungalow, it was once the dominant housing type in this part of the city, but many of the original bungalows have been demolished to make way for larger homes or apartment buildings. The property is a 10-minute walk from the beach, and about 10 minutes from downtown Santa Monica by car.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $800,000 in California
description: A Craftsman bungalow in Santa Monica, a renovated Edwardian house in Oakland and a Tudor Revival cottage in Napa.
content: A Craftsman bungalow in Santa Monica, a renovated Edwardian house in Oakland and a Tudor Revival cottage in Napa.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $800,000 in California
description: A Craftsman bungalow in Santa Monica, a renovated Edwardian house in Oakland and a Tudor Revival cottage in Napa.
content: A Craftsman bungalow in Santa Monica, a renovated Edwardian house in Oakland and a Tudor Revival cottage in Napa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: The Nation Seethes, and Trump’s Response Follows a Pattern
description: Mass protests denounce racial inequality and police violence: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: With protesters expressing a new level of outrage, President Trump blasts back — and Democrats seek to embrace a rising movement. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: A Basketball Brotherhood Calls Timeout
description: A decades-long Manhattan pickup basketball game is on hold because of the pandemic, creating an emotional void for its rotating cast of actors, executives and regular joes.
content: As commissioner of one of New York City’s longstanding pickup basketball games, Dan Feigin always knew where he would be every Saturday morning: inside the subterranean gymnasium at Trevor Day School in Manhattan, where he has worked for nearly three decades as a teacher, coach and administrator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Kettmann
title: When Baseball Comes Back, It Should Look Totally Different
description: After more than a decade of scandal, the sport can reintroduce itself to America by focusing on human drama and emotion.
content: Baseball fans, it won’t be long. Despite the pandemic, the sport has too much to lose to not come back this year, and I predict that games will start again by the Fourth of July. That dramatic timing, with so many hungering for distraction after months of dystopian-novel headlines, could offer baseball a much-needed chance at relevance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattathias Schwartz
title: William Barr’s State of Emergency
description: The attorney general has long held an expansive view of presidential power. With multiple crises converging in the run-up to the 2020 election, he is busy putting his theories to work.
content: On the first Monday in May, the Department of Justice headquarters in Washington was on coronavirus lockdown — or at least it appeared to be from the outside. Signs posted on the outer doors facing Independence Avenue admonished visitors to keep out if they had symptoms of Covid-19 or had been “exposed to any person diagnosed” with it. Inside, the guards operating the X-ray machines wore masks and gloves. Across the lobby, a free-standing pump of hand sanitizer cast a cautionary shadow down empty marble halls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Spanish Gin and a Cocktail, Too
description: Ginraw, a new spirit from Barcelona, showcases Spain’s love for the spirit, and you can try a classic cocktail to go in Manhattan.
content: Spaniards love gin. In Barcelona, there are more than a dozen bars devoted entirely to it. And though gin has been made in Spain for centuries, only a handful of Spanish gins are sold in the United States for that classic “gintonic,” as it’s said in Spain. The latest arrival is Ginraw, made in Barcelona using two distilling methods: the classic copper pot still to create the spirit and, for introducing ingredients like citrus, laurel and cardamom, a low-temperature distilling technique, which is designed to preserve the essences of the botanicals. The gin is notably silky, with a whiff of spice up front and subtle citric richness on the palate. And for a proper gintonic, until bars and restaurants open their doors in New York City, there’s a cocktail stand outside Socarrat Paella Bar on Manhattan’s East Side, where Spanish-style drinks are mixed and sold along with tapas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan and Mike Baker
title: Facing Protests Over Use of Force, Police Respond With More Force
description: Videos showed officers using batons, tear gas, pepper spray and rubber bullets on protesters and bystanders.
content: [Follow our live updates on the George Floyd protests across the country.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Hill, Ainara Tiefenthäler, Christiaan Triebert, Drew Jordan, Haley Willis and Robin Stein
title: 8 Minutes and 46 Seconds: How George Floyd Was Killed in Police Custody
description: The Times has reconstructed the death of George Floyd on May 25. Security footage, witness videos and official documents show how a series of actions by officers turned fatal.
content: On May 25, Minneapolis police officers arrested George Floyd, a 46-year-old black man, after a deli employee called 911, accusing him of buying cigarettes with a counterfeit $20 bill. Seventeen minutes after the first squad car arrived at the scene, Mr. Floyd was unconscious and pinned beneath three police officers, showing no signs of life.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Voices in an America in the Throes of Crisis
description: Readers call on white Americans to “wake up,” question the president’s credibility on police brutality, encourage “taking a knee” in peaceful protest, and more.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trump Takes Us to the Brink
description: Will weaponized racism destroy America?
content: Last fall Bob Kroll, the head of the Minneapolis police union, appeared at a Trump rally, where he thanked the president for ending Barack Obama’s “oppression of police” and letting cops “put the handcuffs on criminals instead of us.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hikari Hida
title: After Reality Star’s Death, Japan Vows to Rip the Mask Off Online Hate
description: While many in the country abhor the kind of harassment Hana Kimura endured before her apparent suicide, some warn that cracking down on it could also chill rising internet activism.
content: TOKYO — During the last weeks of Hana Kimura’s life, a steady stream of hate washed over her social media accounts. On Twitter, Instagram and Facebook, anonymous posters attacked her appearance, her outspoken behavior and especially her role on “Terrace House,” a popular Japanese reality show where some viewers saw her as a villain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Gunna Extends Hip-Hop’s Dominance on the Billboard Album Chart
description: The rapper earned his first No. 1 with “Wunna,” and now all eyes are on Lady Gaga, whose “Chromatica” is expected to take the top spot next week.
content: The Georgia rapper Gunna has taken the top spot on the latest Billboard album chart. And now all eyes in the music industry are on Lady Gaga, whose “Chromatica,” which came out Friday, is a test of the superstar album release during Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Lu
title: There Has Been an Increase in Other Causes of Deaths, Not Just Coronavirus
description: More people have died from heart disease, diabetes and Alzheimer’s disease in New York and New Jersey in recent months than over the same period in previous years. Here’s how those deaths might be linked to the pandemic.
content: More people have died from heart disease, diabetes and Alzheimer’s disease in New York and New Jersey in recent months than over the same period in previous years. Here’s how those deaths might be linked to the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers, Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman
title: As Trump Calls Protesters ‘Terrorists,’ Tear Gas Clears a Path for His Walk to a Church
description: In a Rose Garden speech shaded with anger, President Trump threatened to send the American military to states where governors could not bring under control the protests over police brutality.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Monday angrily denounced the demonstrators who have used violence to call attention to the deaths of black men killed by the police as “organizers” of terrorism, and threatened to send the American military to states where governors could not bring the protests under control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trump Takes Us to the Brink
description: Will weaponized racism destroy America?
content: Last fall Bob Kroll, the head of the Minneapolis police union, appeared at a Trump rally, where he thanked the president for ending Barack Obama’s “oppression of police” and letting cops “put the handcuffs on criminals instead of us.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paresky and Bradley Campbell
title: Safetyism Isn’t the Problem
description: We need to see beyond the stereotypes on both sides of the reopening debate.
content: As America debates when and how to reopen, those concerned about the side effects of the lockdown have begun to use the word “safetyism” to characterize what they consider extreme social-distancing measures.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Widespread Looting Hits Manhattan Before Curfew Begins
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said a citywide curfew would be imposed again on Tuesday, this time at 8 p.m. rather than 11 p.m.
content: New York City hit an 11 p.m. curfew on Monday after widespread looting erupted in the central business district of Manhattan, long a symbol of the city’s prominence, with shattered glass and smashed storefronts on several blocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Biden Slowly Emerges From Seclusion, Hoping to Meet the Moment
description: Joseph Biden is showing that well-timed appearances from quarantine can be effective and powerful, though the dangers of a low profile are likely to escalate.
content: Under normal circumstances, Joseph R. Biden Jr. might have delivered a speech on race in America on Sunday, covered by a press corps following him around the country. He might have visited Minneapolis or another city torn by violence. He might have summoned reporters to the front of his plane to critique President Trump’s leadership of a nation in crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: As Protests Spur Posts From Athletes, N.B.A. Players Take to the Streets
description: The season has been suspended. And the issue of police brutality toward African-Americans has long been a visceral one in a predominantly black league.
content: A broad range of athletes and sports figures have issued statements on social media condemning the killing of George Floyd and other police violence against African-Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As Trump Calls Protesters ‘Terrorists,’ Tear Gas Clears a Path for His Walk to a Church

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Kevin Armstrong
title: How a City Once Consumed by Civil Unrest Has Kept Protests Peaceful
description: Newark, New Jersey’s largest city, made no arrests and reported only minimal property damage during a weekend march.
content: A weekend protest in Newark ended at the same intersection where one of the most wrenching and deadly of the race riots that convulsed the nation during the 1960s began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 5, Episode 5 Recap: Old Men
description: Axe and Chuck grapple with the sins of their fathers. Wendy takes a deeper in interest in art.
content: “Old man, take a look at my life — I’m a lot like you.” This week’s episode of “Billions” uses Neil Young’s song “Old Man” to tie a bow around two of its story lines. In the first, Charles Rhoades Sr. has kidney failure, and his advanced age (and bad habits) makes him an unlikely candidate for a donor. It’s a predicament even his son Chuck’s legal wizardry may be unable to remedy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Virus and Furor Put Inequality on Display
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 1, 2020.
content: “Who we are as a people is greater than the risk to be out there. This is urgent. This isn’t about just our own individual lives as black people, but this is about our futures and children.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Starting to Exercise Again After Lockdown
description: Expert advice on taking it slow to prevent injuries.
content: Q. How do we start exercising again without hurting ourselves after months of lockdown?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Hill, Ainara Tiefenthäler, Christiaan Triebert, Drew Jordan, Haley Willis and Robin Stein
title: 8 Minutes and 46 Seconds: How George Floyd Was Killed in Police Custody
description: The Times has reconstructed the death of George Floyd on May 25. Security footage, witness videos and official documents show how a series of actions by officers turned fatal. (This video contains scenes of graphic violence.)
content: The Times has reconstructed the death of George Floyd on May 25. Security footage, witness videos and official documents show how a series of actions by officers turned fatal. (This video contains scenes of graphic violence.)

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Spice Grinder, Batteries Not Included
description: FinaMill grinds spices from coarse to fine, with removable pods that allow for quick swaps.
content: A sleek new battery-operated spice grinder is light enough for one-handed operation and does nice work on whole spices, offering adjustable textures from coarse to fine. Its accompanying pods can be filled with the spice of your choosing, and they attach to the grinder with just a tap on a countertop. Press the button on top and ground seasonings emerge, even directly over that steak still sizzling on the grill. The smooth exterior of the appliance, which comes in white, red or black, is easily wiped clean. It’s best to run the grinder on empty for half a minute or so to clear it completely before changing spice pods. And despite what the literature suggests about grinding herbs, it cannot handle fresh ones. It runs on three AA batteries; a rechargeable model is in the works. The mill comes with one or two pods, and additional pods are sold separately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Coffee Club Fund-Raises With Special Blends
description: Trade is raising money for its roasters’ communities with Come Together Coffee.
content: Trade, a coffee subscription service that delivers directly from roasters to consumers, is featuring a charitable effort this month to benefit the communities where some of its more than 50 roasters live. In cities across the country, 20 companies have come up with limited-edition roasts for a lineup called Come Together Coffee. Customers can select the roaster from a list that rotates weekly; the profits from the sale will be donated to a charity the roaster chooses. The coffees are $18 for 12 ounces, and a subscription is not required for purchase. Joe Coffee is a participating roaster in New York, with a medium-bodied Peruvian coffee that has pleasing fruity elements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Starting to Exercise Again After Lockdown
description: Expert advice on taking it slow to prevent injuries.
content: Q. How do we start exercising again without hurting ourselves after months of lockdown?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: How Do You Decide if Children Can Play Together Again?
description: As always, parents must weigh the risks, look at what the experts say and make decisions based on their own level of comfort.
content: As some parts of the country “open up” and families venture beyond their households, parents are faced with hard decisions about what children can do. There are no official guidelines, so I asked smart and experienced pediatricians from around the country what questions they are getting from parents, and how they’re answering them. Spoiler alert: There are no easy answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Slider Bun Packed With Whole Grains
description: Angelic Bakehouse has added tiny buns, made from seven sprouted whole grains, to its sandwich-bread lineup.
content: I’ve left Martin for another slider bun. Angelic Bakehouse in Cudahy, Wis., makes its new ones with seven sprouted whole grains and whole-wheat flour, but no chemical additives. All taste mildly wheaty, adding character to summer’s grilled meat patties and sausages. The buns are vegan and kosher. The company also makes wraps, pizza crusts and crackers and has a matching bread donation program for those in need.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: America, Inflamed. Join Us for a Special Conversation About Race.
description: Three New York Times national correspondents who have been reporting from the front lines will provide their insights.
content: In the days since George Floyd died in police custody in Minneapolis, thousands of protesters have spilled into the streets of at least 140 cities to stage demonstrations against police brutality and broader systemic racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Gay Couples Can Teach Straight People a Thing or Two About Arguing
description: Same-sex couples, on average, resolve conflict more constructively than different-sex couples, and with less animosity, studies have shown.
content: Elana Arian and Julia Cadrain, a same-sex couple in Brooklyn, recently fought about a hat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: The Virus Ravaged Parents at One School. They Found a Way to Fight Back.
description: “The level of devastation this small group of people has dealt with, it’s crazy,” said one member of a school committee that is a lifeline for neighbors in Flatbush, Brooklyn.
content: The parent interpreter committee at Public School 315 in Flatbush, Brooklyn, came together late last year to translate school materials for families who were not fluent in English. Soon, as the coronavirus tore through the city, the group found itself navigating life and death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: States Warn That Virus May Doom Climate Projects
description: A billion-dollar program to protect cities from climate change is at risk of failing because of the pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — Connecticut is preparing to build a first-of-its-kind underground flood wall. Virginia has planned an intricate system of berms, pump stations and raised roads to keep the flood-prone city of Norfolk dry. Louisiana has broken ground on a new community for people forced to flee a village on its sinking coast, the country’s first government-resettled climate migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Judge Asks Court Not to ‘Short Circuit’ His Review of Flynn Case
description: A lawyer for the trial judge told an appeals court why he wanted to examine the Justice Department’s “unusual” request to dismiss the charge.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s conduct in abruptly deciding to end the case against President Trump’s former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn was so unusual that it raised a “plausible question” about the legitimacy of the move, a lawyer for the trial judge overseeing that case told a federal appeals court on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Joe Biden Listens to Anguish at a Black Church in Delaware
description: After weeks of virtual events, Mr. Biden went to Bethel A.M.E. Church in Wilmington to hear from community leaders.
content: As the nation entered another day of unrest in response to the killing of George Floyd, who was pinned under a police officer’s knee for nearly nine minutes, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. emerged from isolation to meet with community leaders at a black church in Delaware.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Angelic Bakehouse has added tiny buns, made from seven sprouted whole grains, to its sandwich-bread lineup.

title: Israel’s Plan to Annex the West Bank
description: A former Israeli general cautions against a unilateral move. Another reader says such action is justified.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Laetitia Vancon
title: It’s Made in a Distillery, but You Won’t Smell Any Gin in this Hand Sanitizer
description: The pandemic has forced many European businesses to improvise. This Belgian gin distillery now has a popular line in hand sanitizer.
content: Patrick Kingsley, an international correspondent, and Laetitia Vancon, a photojournalist, are driving more than 3,700 miles to explore the reopening of the European continent after coronavirus lockdowns. Read all their dispatches.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Virus Ravaged Parents at One School. They Found a Way to Fight Back.
description: “The level of devastation this small group of people has dealt with, it’s crazy,” said one member of a school committee that is a lifeline for neighbors in Flatbush, Brooklyn.

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Coronavirus to Shave Trillions From the Economy Over 10 Years
description: The Congressional Budget Office projects a nearly $16 trillion hit to the gross domestic product over the next decade, $7.9 trillion after adjusting for inflation.
content: WASHINGTON — The Congressional Budget Office projected on Monday that the coronavirus pandemic would inflict a serious long-term blow to the United States economy, taking 3 percent off the gross domestic product 10 years from now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel, Mike Isaac, Cecilia Kang and Gabriel J.X. Dance
title: Facebook Employees Stage Virtual Walkout to Protest Trump Posts
description: While Twitter started labeling some of the president’s inflammatory messages, Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, has said his company should leave them alone.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Hundreds of Facebook employees, in rare public criticism on Monday of their own company, protested executives’ decision not to do anything about inflammatory posts that President Trump had placed on the giant social media platform over the past week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Hong Kong Bans Tiananmen Vigil for 1st Time, in New Challenge to Protests
description: Days after China moved to enact new security laws for Hong Kong, the territory’s police rejected permission for an annual vigil to honor the victims of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.
content: Hong Kong on Monday prohibited for the first time the annual June 4 vigil to honor victims of the pro-democracy Tiananmen Square protests in 1989, which the Chinese government crushed with deadly force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández and Benjamin Mueller
title: Global Anger Grows Over George Floyd Death, and Becomes an Anti-Trump Cudgel
description: Public outcries over racism in the United States erupted from Addis Ababa to Vancouver. China and Iran, criticized on human rights by the Trump administration, called the killing of Mr. Floyd a symbol of American hypocrisy.
content: Mass protests over the police killing of another black man in the United States spread globally in the past few days, as many demonstrators not only expressed solidarity with their American counterparts but denounced racism in their own countries.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Christo and Jeanne-Claude’s Grand Projects
description: The installations, often decades in the making and all of them temporary, required the cooperation of numerous people, many of whom had little interest in art.
content: The installations, often decades in the making and all of them temporary, required the cooperation of numerous people, many of whom had little interest in art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Outdoor Coffee Tables
description: Because you need one to anchor any outdoor seating arrangement — and to avoid spilled drinks.
content: On terraces and decks, one piece of furniture is often key to anchoring a seating arrangement: the coffee table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What Is Your Reaction to the Days of Protest That Have Followed the Death of George Floyd?
description: After an African-American man died in policy custody in Minneapolis, thousands have taken to the streets across the country to express their grief, frustration and anger about police violence. Students, we want to hear your thoughts about what is going on.
content: Note: We published our final daily Student Opinion question for the 2019-20 school year on May 29, but felt this news warranted its own space for students to discuss the protests and the issues related to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis and Michael Gonchar
title: Can You Guess the Country? A Geography Photo Quiz for Students
description: For this special edition quiz, we challenge you to test your geography knowledge using photographs from around the world. How many of these 10 questions can you get right?
content: For this special edition quiz, we challenge you to test your geography knowledge using photographs from around the world. How many of these 10 questions can you get right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and Nikita Stewart
title: Symbol of N.Y.C. Unrest: A Burning Police Car
description: So far, 47 police vehicles have been damaged. Some protesters say the attacks reflect pent-up rage against the police, while officials have denounced the violence.
content: On Friday night in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, protesters descended on an unoccupied New York Police Department van, which quickly became the target of all their anger and angst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
content: The International Labor Organization, or I.L.O., is an agency of the United Nations that brings together governments, employers and workers in 187 member states to “set labor standards, develop policies and devise programs promoting decent work for all women and men.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: From Sacramento to San Diego, Californians Join Protests
description: Monday: Snapshots from a chaotic weekend across the state.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Pregnancy Loss Tied to Increased Risk of Type 2 Diabetes
description: Compared with women who had delivered, those who experienced a pregnancy loss were at an 18 percent increased risk for Type 2 diabetes.
content: Loss of a pregnancy may increase a woman’s risk of developing Type 2 diabetes, Danish researchers report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan and Elisabeth Egan
title: Tales From Home, For Home
description: While you’re stuck at home, a selection of novels will let you hang out in someone else’s, whether it’s a mansion, a lighthouse or an apartment building.
content: While you’re stuck at home, a selection of novels will let you hang out in someone else’s, whether it’s a mansion, a lighthouse or an apartment building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: North Carolina Pug Was Not Infected With Coronavirus, U.S.D.A. Says
description: A small amount of the virus was detected in a swab of saliva from Winston, a 2-year-old pug, but he was not infected, the agency said.
content: Winston the pug can breathe a sloppy sigh of relief; he is not the first dog in the United States to be infected with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Putin Sets New Date for Vote on Extending His Rule
description: His political program and ratings derailed by the coronavirus, Russia’s president pushes to get back on track.
content: MOSCOW — Pushing to get his political program back on track, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Monday that a referendum on constitutional changes that would allow him to dispense with term limits and stay in office until 2036 will be held on July 1.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘A Heartbreaking and Painful Week’
description: Business leaders are speaking out about nationwide protests against police brutality and discrimination.
content: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: After Missteps, Pop Stars Apologize … and Sometimes Push Back
description: Lana Del Rey, Doja Cat, and how some in the limelight bristle at social media condemnation.
content: In the last two weeks, the pop stars Lana Del Rey and Doja Cat have both found themselves in hot water on the internet over kerfuffles of their own creation. This is what life online is often like for the famous and demi-famous. Misstep, apologize, recalibrate, repeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Potatoes, Greens and So Much Comfort
description: This riff on an Irish colcannon is among the most filling, nourishing dishes you could make.
content: Cooking, frankly, was the last thing on my mind this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: ‘The Minnesota Paradox’
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Minnesota’s Twin Cities metro area has one of the country’s highest standards of living by many measures: high incomes, long life expectancy, a large number of corporate headquarters and a rich cultural scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandy Jorgenson
title: The Hardest Part of Having a Nonbinary Kid Is Other People
description: A mother recounts the pushback she received from her own family in raising a gender-nonconforming child.
content: I stood in silence next to my kitchen sink, my hands dripping water on to the floor, as my mother berated me for what I had just done. I tried to stay calm as she scoffed, swore, laughed, sighed and grew louder as my two children slept upstairs. Then, without warning, she walked away and closed the guest room door behind her. I found my husband, wrapped my arms around him and cried.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Truck Driver Arrested After Barreling Through Minneapolis Protest
description: The authorities said no one had been struck, but protesters reported that several people may have been injured.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — A man drove a tanker truck toward thousands of protesters on a highway in Minneapolis on Sunday afternoon, coming to a stop only after members of the crowd desperately sprinted out of its path.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Weekend of Pain and Protest
description: Dispatches from cities across the U.S. being rocked by protests over police brutality after the death of George Floyd.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Writers who show us who we are
description: These essays on American authors — some well known, some unjustly forgotten, some perpetually misunderstood — aim to restore a sense of the “complex fate” of being an American. Read more about the series.
content: In the United States right now, it can feel as if all our common experience has been cooked down to a sticky residue of partisanship. But American literature tells a different story — or rather, a great many different stories. To read the work of writers from the near and distant past, and some who are still active, is not necessarily to encounter visions of consensus or progress: Culture wars have always been part of the culture. Still, the homegrown literary imagination has shown the ability to flout, to short-circuit and even to transcend the simplified, sloganized language of politics, embracing what Henry James called the “complex fate” of being an American.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: Watch This: A Poignant Documentary or a Classic Sketch Comedy
description: Your TV needs may vary this week. These are the titles our critic recommends checking out.
content: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Add a Restaurant-Size Salami to Your Table
description: Charlito’s Cocina is selling its trufa seca, a 1.5-pound black truffle salami, to the public.
content: Ten years ago, Charles Wekselbaum was out of a job and decided to pursue his fascination with European meat-curing traditions. He stocked up on heritage pork, and a year later, he started Charlito’s Cocina to sell his handmade dry-cured salami. The story behind the company name? In addition to being Jewish-American, he’s also part Cuban. A factory in Gloversville, N.Y., produces an array of salami,  dry-cured and long-lasting. The salamis are aged at his base of operations in Long Island City, Queens. He is now offering the large, 1.5-pound black truffle (trufa seca) salami ($45), usually reserved for restaurants, to the general public. It conveys just enough of that distinctively funky, truffly perfume and taste. Drink a natural red alongside. It’s available along with the rest of his varieties, in some stores and online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Karan Deep Singh, Caroline Kim and Hari Kumar
title: How India’s Police Used a Pandemic to Boost Its Image
description: The police in New Delhi were roundly vilified for their role in religious violence. Now they’re on the front line of the city’s fight against coronavirus. Our reporters rode along as officers transported sick patients and served meals.
content: The police in New Delhi were roundly vilified for their role in religious violence. Now they’re on the front line of the city’s fight against coronavirus. Our reporters rode along as officers transported sick patients and served meals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Hiroko Masuike
title: Trump, Protesters, Autopsy: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: Facebook and Twitter Must Do More About Trump’s Tweets
description: Twitter is only bringing more attention to the president’s tweets, and Facebook’s strategy has been to do nothing.
content: While Twitter and Facebook dithered over whether to append warning labels on outrageous and dangerous posts from Donald Trump, the president continued to tweet and post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinne Maier
title: A Village Ignored by the Coronavirus
description: Far from Covid-19 hot spots, my neighbors and I endured France’s rigid lockdown rules. We weren’t all sure it was worth it.
content: VIALAS, France — I’m spending the coronavirus lockdown in this tiny village in southern France. Vialas, with only 400 residents, is part of Lozère, the country’s least populated department. Parisians, 400 miles to the north, typically don’t even know where Lozère is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Edward Wong
title: As Virus Toll Preoccupies U.S., Rivals Test Limits of American Power
description: The coronavirus may have changed almost everything, but it didn’t change this: Global competition spins ahead — and in many ways has accelerated.
content: WASHINGTON — With the United States preoccupied by the sobering reality of more than 100,000 Americans dead from the coronavirus, China has pushed in recent weeks to move troops into disputed territory with India, continue aggressive actions in the South China Sea and rewrite the rules of how it will control Hong Kong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
title: Netanyahu’s Annexation Plans Meet Surprise Opponent: Israeli Settlers
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has promised to annex much of the occupied West Bank. But now that he can, there are questions about whether he will.
content: JERUSALEM — Having crushed his political opponents and won a new term, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has cleared a path to fulfilling his most polarizing campaign promise: annexing occupied West Bank territory, the long-held dream of right-wing Jewish settlers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Outdoor Coffee Tables
description: Because you need one to anchor any outdoor seating arrangement — and to avoid spilled drinks.
content: On terraces and decks, one piece of furniture is often key to anchoring a seating arrangement: the coffee table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
content: The International Labor Organization, or I.L.O., is an agency of the United Nations that brings together governments, employers and workers in 187 member states to “set labor standards, develop policies and devise programs promoting decent work for all women and men.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: From Sacramento to San Diego, Californians Join Protests
description: Monday: Snapshots from a chaotic weekend across the state.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Christo and Jeanne-Claude’s Grand Projects
description: The installations, often decades in the making and all of them temporary, required the cooperation of numerous people, many of whom had little interest in art.
content: The installations, often decades in the making and all of them temporary, required the cooperation of numerous people, many of whom had little interest in art.

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Potatoes, Greens and So Much Comfort
description: This riff on an Irish colcannon is among the most filling, nourishing dishes you could make.
content: Cooking, frankly, was the last thing on my mind this weekend.

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Pat Dye, Football Coach Who Elevated Auburn, Dies at 80
description: He reshaped the very architecture and culture of the Iron Bowl rivalry and led Auburn to four conference titles.
content: Pat Dye, who revived Auburn University’s football program into a power of the Southern gridiron but ultimately saw his reputation and that of the school undercut by scandal, died Monday. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pandemic to Cost U.S. Economy $7.9 Trillion Over 10 Years
description: Michigan’s governor lifted a stay-at-home order as other states announced steps to reopen. For a second day, Wuhan reported no new infections.
content: The Congressional Budget Office projected on Monday that the pandemic would inflict a devastating long-term blow on the United States economy, costing $7.9 trillion over the next decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles and Audra D. S. Burch
title: How Did George Floyd Die? Here’s What We Know
description: A private autopsy commissioned by the family concluded that his death was a homicide, brought about by compression of his neck and back by Minneapolis police officers.
content: George Floyd, 46, died after being handcuffed on the street in the custody of the Minneapolis police on Memorial Day. An officer responding to a report that Mr. Floyd had tried to pass a fake $20 bill helped hold him down by lodging a knee on his neck for nearly nine minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pandemic to Cost U.S. Economy $7.9 Trillion Over 10 Years
description: Michigan’s governor lifted a stay-at-home order as other states announced steps to reopen. For a second day, Wuhan reported no new infections.
content: The Congressional Budget Office projected on Monday that the pandemic would inflict a devastating long-term blow on the United States economy, costing $7.9 trillion over the next decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Six Months of Coronavirus: Here’s Some of What We’ve Learned
description: Much remains unknown and mysterious, but these are some of the things we’re pretty sure of after half a year of this pandemic.
content: We don’t really know when the novel coronavirus first began infecting people. But as we turn a page on our calendars into June, it is fair to say that Sars-Cov-2 has been with us now for a full six months.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tear Gas Clears Path for Trump to Visit Church
description: Police officers also used flash grenades to disperse a crowd so Mr. Trump could visit for a photo opportunity. And in New York, protesters and looters defied a curfew.
content: In his first remarks from the White House since massive protests have swept the country, President Trump said Monday evening that the looting and violent demonstrations in reaction to the death of George Floyd in police custody were “acts of domestic terror.”
source.name: The New York Times
